problem: Find the last two digits of the following sum: $$5! + 10! + 15! + \cdots + 100!$$
solution: Since for all $n \ge 10$, $n!$ has (at least) two factors of 5, we know that $n!$ will end in two zeros.  Therefore, if $n\ge 10$, then $n!$ contributes nothing to the last two digits of the sum. So we need only compute $5! = 120$, and hence our answer is $\boxed{20}$.
model_solution:
Step 1:  We are required to find the last two digits of the sum of factorials: $5! + 10! + 15! + \cdots + 100!$
Step 2:  The last two digits of a number are equivalent to the number modulo 100. This means we need to find the value of the given sum modulo 100.
Step 3:  Since $10! = 3628800$, we can see that for any $n \geq 10$, the factorial $n!$ will be divisible by 100. This is because $10!$ itself is divisible by 100, and any larger factorial will be an even multiple of 10!.
Step 4:  So, we can conclude that for all terms starting from $10!$ onwards, their last two digits will be 00.
Step 5:  This reduces our problem to finding the last two digits of $5!$.
Step 6:  We can calculate $5!$ by multiplying the numbers from 1 to 5 together: $5! = 5 \times 4 \times 3 \times 2 \times 1 = 120$
Step 2: 
Since the last two digits of $5!$ are $20$, and all the other terms have a last two digits of $00$, the sum $5! + 10! + 15! + \cdots + 100!$ will have the same last two digits as $5!$, which is $20$.
Since the last two digits of $5!$ are $20$, and all the other terms have a last two digits of $00$, the sum $5! + 10! + 15! + \cdots + 100!$ will have the same last two digits as $5!$, which is $20$.
The last two digits of the sum are $20$.
The last two digits of the sum are $20$.
